issues.description: Template Person entity declares the id field as java.util.UUID, while the rest of the template/solution code (PersonRepository, service/resource method signatures, and tests) use Long as the entity id type. This mismatch is a structural type inconsistency: the repository is declared as JpaRepository<Person, Long> and repository query methods accept Long, but the entity's id getter/setter are of type UUID. This will cause compilation/runtime problems and confusion for students (e.g., mismatched generic types, incorrect comparisons between path-variable Long IDs and UUID ids, and failing to follow the intended solution which uses Long).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the entity id type consistent with the repository and tests. Change the id field in the template Person.java from java.util.UUID to Long (update the field declaration, getter, setter, and any imports) so it matches JpaRepository<Person, Long> and the rest of the code/tests. Alternatively (less preferred given provided solution and tests), change the repository generic types and all method signatures/uses to UUID consistently. Prefer aligning the template to the solution (use Long) to avoid blocking students.

issues.description: The template Person entity declares its primary key field as java.util.UUID (Person.id of type UUID), while the repository generics, service/resource method signatures, tests, and the solution use Long for the person id. This mismatch (UUID vs Long) refers to the same conceptual entity (the person's identifier) but with different types across artifacts. Students will be confused when mapping the problem/tests (which expect Long ids) to the template entity; this can lead to compilation/runtime/test failures and extra cognitive burden resolving the discrepancy.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the identifier type consistent across all artifacts. The least intrusive fix is to change the template Person.id declaration and its getter/setter from java.util.UUID to Long (update imports and related methods/equals/hashCode accordingly) so it matches the repository generics, resource/service method signatures, tests, and the solution. Alternatively, if you prefer UUIDs, update the repository generics, resource/service signatures, and tests to use UUID everywhere — but prefer aligning the template to Long to match the existing repository/tests and solution.
